objdescid.compdate: c. 1785-90The date is based on stylistic considerations.

provenance.name: British Museum
provenance.note: Acquired at an unknown time by John Deffett Francis and given by him to the British Museum in Dec. 1874.

repository.addressline: Email, Department of Prints and Drawings: prints@britishmuseum.org

objnote.p: For the water color drawing on the recto of this leaf, see A Man and Woman Kneeling and Warming Themselves at a Fire.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the center of the composition, a nude dog-headed figure, likely Anubis, sits facing left with his left arm dangling by his side. His one pictured leg, the left, is bent at the knee and his foot appears to rest on a form lower left, perhaps a stone. A diagonal, somewhat serpentine line suggests that the figure is seated on a bank or cliff. This drawing may be related to the design by Fuseli which Blake engraved for Erasmus Darwin's Botanic Garden, 1791, but is not a direct preliminary for that engraving.

component.illusobjdesc: In the center of the composition, a nude dog-headed figure, likely Anubis, sits facing left with his left arm dangling by his side. His mouth appears to be slightly open, perhaps with the hint of a smile. His one pictured leg is bent and his left foot appears to rest on a form lower left, perhaps a stone. He may be sitting on a bank or cliff, as indicated by the lines upper right and the line below his leg.

The dog-headed figure of Anubis appears to rest his one pictured foot, the left, on a form demarcated by a single line lower left, perhaps a stone or part of the bank or cliff suggested by the line upper right.
A diagonal, somewhat serpentine line suggests that the figure may be seated on a bank or cliff.
